snippet: Contrary to the perception that art collectors are flipping art to make a quick profit, two analyses show that the resale pace last year was only slightly faster than it was in the mid-1990s.
abstract: Statistical analysis reveals that artworks are being resold at auction at only a slightly higher pace than in the mid-1990s; findings contradict widespread perception that a new breed of collectors are flipping artworks for quick profits at unprecedented rates.

byline.original: By LORNE MANLY and ROBIN POGREBIN

lead_paragraph: Contrary to the perception that art collectors are flipping art to make a quick profit, two analyses show that the resale pace last year was only slightly faster than it was in the mid-1990s.

headline.main: Barbarians at the Art Auction Gates? Not to Worry
headline.print_headline: Barbarians at the Art Auction Gates? Not to Worry
